children.name: disagree
children.definition: to have a different opinion about sth from sb else: bất đồng ý kiến, không đồng ý
examples: A lot of people think that capitalism is the only system that works, but I disagree.
disagree with
▪ I showed my article to the editor. He disagreed with almost everything I’d written.
disagree about
▪ Throughout their marriage my parents disagreed about whether to stay in their hometown or not.
disagree that
▪ The company’s lawyers disagreed that the complaint was a criminal matter.
strongly disagree
▪ The court decision represents an issue on which the president and the Justice Department strongly disagree.

children.name: not agree
children.definition: /nɒt əˈgriː/  to disagree with someone about a subject or about what to do: không đồng ý
examples: ▪ He thinks we’d have a better chance of finding work if we moved house, but I don’t agree.
not agree with
▪ I’d never vote for Davies. He has too many policies I don’t agree with.
not agree on/about
▪ Before long, they realized that they couldn’t agree about anything.
▪ We couldn’t agree on what to do in the afternoon, so we just stayed at home.
not agree that
▪ The doctor did not agree that the only solution was to operate.

children.name: not see eye to eye
children.definition: /nɒt siː ˌaɪ tʊ ˈaɪ/  if two people do not see eye to eye, they have very different opinions and ideas, so that it is difficult for them to be friends or to work together: không đồng quan điểm
examples: not see eye to eye on/about:
▪ Unfortunately, Julie and I don’t see eye to eye on money matters.
not see eye to eye with: bất đồng quan điểm với ai
▪ Donato doesn’t see eye to eye with several of the other committee members.

children.name: take issue with
children.definition: formal to disagree strongly with someone about something they have said or done, and to argue with them about it:
examples: take issue with sb over sth
I took issue with Meeker over the way he was running the company.

children.name: differ
children.definition: /ˈdɪfəʳ/  especially written if a group of people differ about something, they have a range of different opinions on it:
examples: differ about/over
▪ Critics differed about the importance of Osborne’s new play.
▪ All politicians agree that inflation must be beaten but they differ over methods of achieving this.
differ widely: differ a lot
▪ Scholars differ widely about when the two manuscripts were written.

children.name: agree to disagree
children.definition: / agree to differBritish /əˌgriː tə ˌdɪsəˈgriː, əˌgriː tə ˈdɪfəʳ/  to stop arguing with someone about something and accept that they cannot be persuaded to agree with you :
examples: chấp nhận sự bất đồng ( không thể thuyết phục được nữa )
▪ The two sides had agreed to differ.
Hai bên đã đồng ý khác nhau.
▪ After two days, the negotiators had done little more than agree to disagree.
Sau hai ngày, các nhà đàm phán đã làm ít hơn đồng ý không đồng ý.

children.name: dissent
children.definition: /dɪˈsent/  formal to say publicly that you disagree with an official opinion or belief, or one that is accepted by most people:
examples: ▪ The decision was supported by almost everyone. Baldwin was the only one to dissent.
dissent from
▪ No one dared dissent from the official party line.
dissenting voicespeople who say they disagree: giọng nói phản đối
▪ Blair would be wise to listen to some of the dissenting voices in his party.

children.name: controversial
children.definition: something that is controversial causes a lot of disagreement and angry argument, especially in the newspaper, on television etc: gây nhiều tranh cãi
examples: A recent government paper on education contains some controversial new ideas.
Rossellini’s controversial film, ‘The Miracle’
The decision to use the bomb remains the most controversial question of the Second World War.

children.name: contentious
children.definition: issue/ subject/ problem etcone that is likely to cause a lot of disagreement and argument: gây nhiều tranh cãi
examples: ▪ Abortion has always been a contentious subject.
▪ the contentious issue of arms sales to non-democratic countries

children.name: bone of contention
children.definition: a subject that people strongly disagree about for alongtimeand often argue about:vấn đề gây tranh cãi
examples: The new tax on property is likely to become a serious bone of contention.
bone of contention between
The way we manage money has been the only real bone of contention between us.

children.name: be at loggerheads
children.definition: /biː ət ˈlɒgəʳhedzǁ-ˈlɔːg-/  iftwopeople orgroupsare at loggerheads, they strongly disagree with each other and argue, usually about how to deal with a problem or decision:
examples: ( 2 người, 2 nhóm ) bất hòa ( về 1 quyết định, hướng giải quyết vấn đề )
▪ As a result of the strike, neighbours and even families were soon at loggerheads.
Kết quả của cuộc đình công, hàng xóm và thậm chí cả gia đình đã sớm bất hòa
be at loggerheads over/about: bất hòa về
▪ Congress and the President are still at loggerheads over how to balance the federal budget.
Quốc hội và Tổng thống vẫn còn gặp bất hòa về cách cân bằng ngân sách liên bang.

children.name: be at odds
children.definition: /biː ət ˈɒdzǁ-ˈɑːdz/  to disagree with a person, organization, or way of thinking and be opposed to them - used especially in news reports: bất hòa
examples: be at odds with
▪ Britain and France were constantly at odds with each other throughout the negotiations.
be at odds over: bất hòa về
▪ The two sides are still at odds over a pay increase for airline pilots.

children.name: fall out
children.definition: /ˌfɔːl ˈaʊt/  British to disagree strongly with sb and argue with them about it so that your good relationship with them is damaged: xích mích
examples: ▪ Jung and Freud fell out when Jung disagreed with some of Freud’s central theories.
fall out with
▪ Maria fell out with some of her colleagues and decided to look for a new job.
fall out (with sb) over
▪ They fell out over some stupid little issue.
họ xích mích với nhau về một vài vấn đề nhỏ
falling-out[singular noun]xích mích
▪ She was fired from the Broadway production after a highly-publicized falling-out with Weber.
Cô đã bị sa thải khỏi nhà hát Broadway sau khi bị xích mích với Weber

children.name: be in conflict with
children.definition: /biː ɪn ˈkɒnflɪkt wɪð ǁ-ˈkɑːn-/  to strongly disagree with someone and to be continuously opposing them and arguing against their actions and intentions:
examples: xung đột với ai
▪ Rather than be in continual conflict with his boss, Bruce moved to another job.
Thay vì liên tục xung đột với ông chủ, Bruce đã chuyển sang một công việc khác.
▪ Union leaders are again in conflict with management, this time over job losses.
Lãnh đạo Liên minh lại xung đột với quản lý, lần này là mất việc làm.

children.name: irreconcilable
children.definition: /ɪˌrekənˈsaɪləbəl◂/  having or resulting from such completely different aims or opinions that agreement is impossible:
examples: không thể hòa giải được, hàn gắn được
▪ The split in the Liberal party seems to be irreconcilable.
Sự chia rẽ trong đảng Tự do dường như không thể hòa giải được.
irreconcilable differences: sự khác biệtkhông thể hòa giải được, hàn gắn được
▪ When irreconcilable differences exist between two people, it is better that they should separate.
Khi có sự khác biệt không thể hòa hợp được giữa hai người, tốt hơn là họ nên tách biệt.
irreconcilable with: không thể hòa giải được với ai
▪ Both these ways of looking at the world are valid but utterly irreconcilable with each other.

children.name: cause disagreement
children.definition: give rise to/lead to//gɪv ˌraɪz tuː, ˌliːd tuː, ˌkɔːz dɪsəˈgriːmənt/
examples: dẫn đến sự bất đồng
▪ The issue of organ cloning has given rise to some disagreement among doctors.
Vấn đề nhân bản các cơ quan đã làm tăng sự bất đồng giữa các bác sĩ.
▪ It was Garcia’s plan to redistribute land that caused the most disagreement.
Kế hoạch phân phối lại đất của Garcia đã gây ra sự bất đồng lớn
▪ His speech is bound to lead to some disagreement, but I think most people will accept it.
Bài phát biểu của ông buộc phải dẫn đến một số bất đồng, nhưng tôi nghĩ hầu hết mọi người sẽ chấp nhận nó.

children.name: divide
children.definition: /dɪˈvaɪd, dəˈvaɪd/  to cause strong disagreement among agroupof people so that they separate and form different groups with different opinions:
examples: chia tách, chia rẽ ( nhóm người )
▪ The election campaign was bitter, dividing the city.
Chiến dịch bầu cử cay đắng, chia rẽ thành phố.
▪ The issue dividing the Church was the question of women priests.
Vấn đề phân chia Giáo Hội là vấn đề của các linh mục nữ.

children.name: split
children.definition: /splɪt/  to causestrongdisagreement among agroupof people so that it is divided intotwosmaller groups-use this especially aboutpoliticalgroups or political ideas:
examples: chia tách , chia rẽ ( 1 nhóm thành hai, thường là về chính trị )
▪ When the book appeared just before the end of the century, it almost split the feminist movement.
Khi cuốn sách xuất hiện ngay trước cuối thế kỷ, nó gần như phân chia phong trào nữ quyền.
split the country/party etc down the middlesplit it into two equal and opposing groups:
chia tách quốc gia/ đảng thành 2 phe đối lập
▪ Feelings about the war split the country right down the middle.
Chiến tranh chia cắt đất nước thành 2 phe đối lập

children.name: when members of a group disagree
divided
children.definition: be  if a group of people is divided over sth, some of them support one opinion and others support a completely different one:bị chia rẽ
examples: be divided over/on
The country’s leaders appear to bedevidedon the question of tax cuts.
division[countable/uncountable noun] disagreement among the members of a group that causes it to separate into smaller groups, each with a different opinion:
There are signs of growing division within the administration about the best strategy to adopt.
division over
There was a deep division in the Republican Party over policy on Central America.

children.name: split
children.definition: be C2 if a group of people is divided or split over sth, some of them support one opinion and others support a completely different one: bị chia rẽ
examples: be divided/split over/on:
The country’s leaders appear to be split on the question of tax cuts.
Foreign aid agencies were split over whether to resume their operations in the troubled country.
split[C] a serious disagreement that divides an organization or group into two smaller groups: sự chia rẽ, phân chia
There is great danger of a split in the party if a competent leader is not found soon.
split over
There is a deep split in the country over the best way to move forward the peace process.

children.name: rift
children.definition: /rɪft/  aseriousdisagreement that divides a group for a verylongtimeor prevents two people or organizations from continuing to live or work together:rạn nứt
examples: ▪ It took a good five years for the rift within the party to mend.
rift between
▪ The family arguments finally caused a rift between the mother and daughter that has not yet healed.

children.name: disagreement
children.definition: /ˌdɪsəˈgriːmənt/  when people disagree with each other: sự bất đồng
examples: ▪ The party is seriously split by internal rivalries and disagreements.
disagreement about/over: sựbất đồng về
▪ Disagreement over who should produce the next album caused the band to split.
disagreement between/among : bất đồng giữa 2 người/ nhiều người
▪ There is some disagreement among medical experts about the best treatment for back pain.
Có một số bất đồng giữa các chuyên gia về cách điều trị tốt nhất cho bệnh đau lưng.

children.name: difference of opinion
children.definition: when people are unable to agree, especially about something important - use this as a way of avoiding more direct words like ‘argument’ and ‘disagreement’:sự bất đồng quan điểm
examples: difference of opinion about/over
There were major differences of opinion over who should command the UN forces.
difference of opinion between/among :
There is a difference of opinion between the chairman and the board as to the best way to handle the takeover.

children.name: controversy
children.definition: /ˈkɒntrəvɜːsi, kənˈtrɒvəsiǁˈkɑːntrəvɜːrsi/  aseriousdisagreement about a decision, plan, or action, that causes arguments for a long timein newspapers, on television etc: sự tranh cãi ( trên các phương tiện thông tin đại chúng )
examples: ▪ Controversy surrounds the TV show, which many consider to be racist, sexist, and homophobic.
controversy over: sự tranh luận, tranh cãi về
▪ There has been a huge controversy over where to put the city’s new sports stadium and who should build it.

children.name: deadlock
children.definition: /stalemate a situation in which two groups disagree, and no agreement is possible because each group refuses to change its mind even slightly:bế tắc
examples: Parents believe that pressure from city hall could force an end to the stalemate with the school board
deadlock/stalemate over
the political deadlock over allowable levels of greenhouse emissions
break the deadlock/stalemateend the situation:
US negotiators met with representatives from both countries today in an attempt to break thedeadlock.

children.name: friction
children.definition: continuousdisagreement and angry feelings or unfriendliness between people:sự vạ chạm, xích mích, đụng độ
examples: Teenage children begin to assert their independence and this can lead to a good deal of friction in the family.
friction between
There has been serious friction between the two army commanders.

children.name: discord
children.definition: /ˈdɪskɔːʳd/ formalstrong disagreement that makes people feel unfriendly towards each other:
examples: bất hòa
▪ Money is the single biggest cause of discord in marriage.
Tiền là nguyên nhân lớn nhất gây nên sự bất hòa trong hôn nhân.
discord over: bất hòa về điều gì
▪ There has always been discord over NATO’s role in world conflict.
Luôn luôn có sự bất hòa về vai trò của NATO trong xung đột thế giới.

children.name: dissent
children.definition: /dɪˈsent/  a refusal to accept anofficialopinion or an opinion thatmostpeopleaccept:
examples: bất đồng ( về một quan điểm chính thức hay hầu hết mọi người chấp nhận )
▪ During the Prime Minister’s speech there were several murmurs of open dissent from the crowd.
Trong bài phát biểu của Thủ tướng Chính phủ, có một số lời mâu thuẫn về sự bất đồng quan điểm từ đám đông.
▪ Anti-war dissent was increasing by the time Nixon took office.
Sự bất đồng về chiến tranh đã tăng lên khi Nixon lên nắm quyền.

children.name: nonsense
children.definition: /rubbishUK spoken use this when you strongly disagree with sth sb has said : Vô lí ( nói để bày tỏ sự không đồng ý )
examples: ‘You always think you’re right!’ ‘Nonsense!’

children.name: conflict
children.definition: nounxung đột; cuộc xung đột
examples: an active disagreement between people with opposing opinions or principles
_There was a lot of conflictbetweenhim and his father.
_It was an unpopular policy and caused a number of conflicts within the party.
_His outspoken views would frequentlybringhimintoconflictwiththe president.

children.name: trouble
children.definition: nounDIFFICULTIES
examples: [ U ] problems in the form of arguments, fighting or violence
_Listen, I don't want any trouble in here, so please just finish your drink and leave.
_You can only go to the match if you promise to leaveat the first sign oftrouble.
_My little brother's always trying tostir up
(= create) troublebetweenme and my boyfriend.

children.name: scene
children.definition: nounARGUMENTtrận cãi lộn
examples: [ C ] an expression of great anger or similar feelings, often
between two people, or an occasion when this happens
_Please don'tmakea scene.
_There was a terrible scene and Jayne ended up in tears.

children.name: war
children.definition: nouncuộcchiến
examples: any situation in which there is strong competition between
opposing sides or a greatfight against something harmful
_The past few months have witnessed apricewar between leading supermarkets.
_The government are to step up their attempt towagewaragainst/ondrugs.
